Used in #15373.

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [038a2773e5](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16768/commits/038a2773e5d458470186d64d0ea22f1d08b945b7)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Filter.EventuallyEq.div_mul_cancel`
`+ Filter.EventuallyEq.div_mul_cancel_atTop`
`+ Tendsto.den`
`+ Tendsto.num`
`+ Tendsto.num_atTop_iff_den_atTop`
`+ bdd_le_mul_tendsto_zero`
`+ bdd_le_mul_tendsto_zero'`
`+ preimage_const_mul_Ioi_or_Iio`
`+ tendsto_bdd_div_atTop_nhds_zero`
`+ tendsto_mod_div_atTop_nhds_zero_nat`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
A stupid remark: do you want "quotients" of "fractions" in the PR title?

I added a commit with a little bit of cleanup, this looks good now. (I see that many other results in this file are also about just multiplication, but stated for fields, so that is fine for this as well).

bors d+

:v: mariainesdff can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11446758627/job/31846618476)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11446758627/job/31846619002)
This is proved for a positive constant, not a nonzero one

```suggestion
/-- If there exist real constants `b` and `B` such that for `n` big enough, `b ≤ f n ≤ B`, then
```
Should all these be explicit arguments?
I have made `f`, `b` and `B` implicit.

```suggestion
  all_goals filter_upwards [hb, hB, Ioi_mem_atTop 0] with n _ _ _; gcongr
```

:golf: `aesop` is nice. :smile: 
```suggestion
    Tendsto (fun n : ℕ => ((n % m : ℕ) : ℝ) / (n : ℝ)) atTop (𝓝 0) :=
  tendsto_bdd_div_atTop_nhds_zero_nat (b := 0) (B := m) (by aesop) <|
    .of_forall fun n ↦ by exact_mod_cast (mod_lt n hm).le
```

There are several issues here:

1. This should be called: `Filter.EventuallyEq.div_mul_cancel`
2. It shouldn't be specialized to `atTop` or `ℕ`
3. It shouldn't be specialized to `ℝ` and make use of coercions.

Instead, it should be something like this:

```lean
theorem Filter.EventuallyEq.div_mul_cancel {α G : Type*} [GroupWithZero G] {f g : α → G}
    {l : Filter α} (hg : Tendsto g l (𝓟 {0}ᶜ)) : (fun x ↦ f x / g x * g x) =ᶠ[l] fun x ↦ f x := by
  filter_upwards [hg.le_comap <| preimage_mem_comap (m := g) (mem_principal_self {0}ᶜ)] with x hx
  aesop

theorem Filter.EventuallyEq.div_mul_cancel_atTop {α G : Type*} [LinearOrderedSemifield G]
    {f g : α → G} {l : Filter α} (hg : Tendsto g l atTop) :
    (fun x ↦ f x / g x * g x) =ᶠ[l] fun x ↦ f x :=
  div_mul_cancel <| hg.mono_right <| le_principal_iff.mpr <|
    mem_of_superset (Ioi_mem_atTop 0) <| by aesop
```

This doesn't *quite* get you what you need because of the coercions, but it's very close, and easily applied by using [tendsto_natCast_atTop_atTop](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/AtTopBot/Archimedean.html#tendsto_natCast_atTop_atTop).

Does that seem reasonable to you?
Thanks, I have replaced the previous lemma by these two.
This also seems too specialized. Certainly it shouldn't need functions from `ℕ → ℕ`. Can you try to generalize it more along the lines I specified for the previous one?

I generalized it to
```lean
theorem Tendsto.num {α G : Type*} [Preorder α] [LinearOrderedField G] [TopologicalSpace G]
    [OrderTopology G] {f g : α → G} (hg : Tendsto g atTop atTop) {a : G} (ha : 0 < a)
    (hlim : Tendsto (fun x => f x / g x) atTop (𝓝 a)) :
    Tendsto f atTop atTop
```

Can the filter on the domain be generalized to an arbitary filter?
Can you turn this into an `iff` with `hg`?
I generalized the filter on the domain. For the `iff` version, I had to add a `[ContinuousInv K]` hypothesis.

```suggestion
/-- If `g` tends to `∞` , then eventually for all `x` we have
```
(or similar)

The denominator can be an arbitrary function that tends to `atTop`? And then the domain filter can also be generalized. And then the domain and codomain can be generalized here as well, I think.

Optionally: assume that eventually `f n \in Icc b B` to have 1 instead of 2 hypotheses.
You can take inspiration from `Filter.Tendsto.div_atTop` although your hypothesis on `f` is weaker (and probably your result should be moved there).

Do you know if we have something like
```lean
theorem foo {α K : Type*} [Nonempty α] [SemilatticeSup α] [LinearOrderedField K] 
    [TopologicalSpace K] [OrderTopology K] {f g : α → K} {b : K}
    (hb : ∀ᶠ x in atTop, b ≤ f x) {B : K} (hB : ∀ᶠ x in atTop, f x ≤ B)
    (hg : Tendsto g atTop (𝓝 0)) :
    Tendsto (fun x ↦ f x * (g x)) atTop (𝓝 0)
```
?
(I cannot find it).

Loogling `Filter.Tendsto _ _ (nhds 0), _ * _` I found [Filter.isBoundedUnder_le_mul_tendsto_zero](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Field/Lemmas.html#Filter.isBoundedUnder_le_mul_tendsto_zero), which is very close.
I could not adapt that proof but I found an alternative one. I would appreciate help golfing it.

Please generalize to ordered ring (and move again to another file)
Please update docstring (also elsewhere).
Can you generalize the `atTop` filter in the domain of all functions (also elsewhere)? It should work for any filter (and with less structure on `\a`).

In the proof, some simplifications:
* `squeeze_zero'` is a better squeeze theorem for the absolute value (it uses lower bound 0)
* Your first line `obtain ⟨nf, hnf⟩ := eventually_atTop.mp hf` is not needed. To use `hf`, it's nicer to use the tactic `filter_upwards [hf]`. (also in later proofs)

I looked into generalizing, but I was not sure where this lemma would fit in, for two reasons:
- There is no `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Order.Ring` (which would be the natural guess).
- There are already several lemmas in `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Order.Field` which only use multiplication, which seems like an argument to also leave this lemma here (at least until the others are generalized, if possible).

I will look into the simplifications.
The reason I did not use `squeeze_zero'` is that it is not imported in this file and I did not want to modify the imports.

I guess you can use `OrderedRing + ContinuousMul` or something? If there is no natural other file for this lemma (yet), feel free to leave it here.

I didn't realize about the imports for `squeeze_zero'`. I guess then you can still simplify the proof by using `0` as lower bound.
I simplified as suggested.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis/SpecificLimits/Basic): add lemmas about limits of fractions
